awd_titl_txt: Scholarships For Excellence, Achievement, and Professional Competence in Science, Math, and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Contra Costa College (CCC) is a two-year Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) located in San Pablo 20 miles north of Oakland/San Francisco and 50 miles north of Silicon Valley, offering associate degree programs and certificate programs in a variety of STEM fields. This five-year project will recruit high ability, low-income students in biological science, computer sciences, engineering, mathematics, and the physical sciences, to receive mentoring and academic support so as to reduce time to associate degree completion. Four cohorts of 30 students each will participate. Research opportunities and internships for students will be coordinated by the Center for Science at Contra Costa College, which engages in collaborative partnerships with many regional National laboratories and local industries.

Peer Lead Team Learning (PLTL) will be utilized to deepen conceptual knowledge and understanding.  A learning community will be built through participation in the Center for Science, which models the approach of Uri Treisman for student support. Experts from the Lawrence Hall of Science will oversee the research aspects of this project.  Together with members of the principal investigator (PI) team, they will study whether or not reducing students' financial burden helps them to complete their academic goals, whether or not summer bridge activities improve the STEM pipeline, and how the PLTL model helps student learning and increases student success.  Broader impacts will be gained via workforce development opportunities for students as well as promoting transfer to 4-year institutions. Metrics for evaluating the project's implementation activities will include short-term goals for scholarship recipients (e.g. 85% year-to-year retention), mid-term goals for transferring to a baccalaureate institution (80% of scholars transfer within three years), and long-term graduation goals for the transfer students (90% attaining a baccalaureate degree within six years).

por.por_cntn:
Contra Costa College (CCC) S-STEM Scholars Project

Contra Costa College (CCC) is a public, urban community college located in West Contra Costa County, 25 miles east of San Francisco, California. According to the fall 2022 data from the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES), 78% of the students received some form of financial aid, and 48% received Pell Grants. The college enrollment consisted of 18% Asians, 14% Black or African American, 45% Hispanic, 12% White, 6% two or more races, and others.

The CCC S-STEM Scholars Project was created with the following goals:

  • Improved educational opportunities for students: To provide opportunities for a greater number of low-income and underrepresented students to complete an associate degree in STEM and/or transfer to a baccalaureate STEM program.
  • Increased retention of students to degree achievement: To engage students in new learning strategies through cohort development and learning communities.
  • Increased student support programs at institutions of higher education: To provide an array of support services to ensure the successful progression of students from entry to degree completion and into careers in STEM fields.
  • Increased the number of well-educated and skilled employees in technical areas of need: To provide more STEM graduates from underrepresented groups to meet the burgeoning regional and national need and expand diversity in the technology workforce.

We achieved these goals using a multipronged approach:

  • Selecting up to 30 students each year and enrolling them in courses of study in science, mathematics, English, and engineering.
  • Providing academic advising through the counseling office and weekly mentor meetings.
  • Offering academic support activities through workshops and tutoring.
  • Providing selected students with work and research experience that shows the real practice of science and engineering.
  • Organizing scientifically relevant seminars and discussions twice a month.
  • Organizing academic trips to places with a focus on science, technology, and engineering.
  • Encouraging the participation of science faculty in activities that increase their knowledge and abilities in how students can learn to do science.

The CCC S-STEM Scholars Project has a devoted cadre of mentors and advisors from the college and STEM-related institutions. These individuals are experienced scientists who share their knowledge and provide emotional and moral support to our students.

STEM participants are also given opportunities to attend conferences and talks. Students have had the opportunity to meet and hear from leading scientists and engineers, as well as discover exciting developments in technology.

During the COVID-19 lockdown, we continued our support program remotely. Thus, our funding allowed us to extend the support program to eight years.

Results:

We have served a total of 194 students, mostly women, low-income, and/or from underrepresented groups in STEM. Of these, 158 students (81.4%) persisted in the program, while 36 students (18.6%) left due to various reasons, including dropping out of school, changing majors, transferring schools, relocating, or work-related issues. Of the 158 persisting students, 106 (54.6%) have transferred, and 52 (26.8%) will continue at CCC, supported by other funding sources.

Based on our data and various communication methods (email, text message, Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn), we have gathered information on S-STEM students who have transferred. Of the 106 students who have transferred, the results from the eight years are as follows:

Transfer Schools:

  • Universities of California: 68
  • California State Universities: 32
  • Private/Out-of-State Universities: 6
  • Total transfer students: 106

Status of Transfer Students:

  • Graduated with a bachelor’s degree: 60
  • In bachelor’s degree program: 30
  • No information found: 16
  • In graduate school: 14
  • Working in STEM-related fields (while in bachelor's program and/or after graduation with a bachelor’s degree): 75

The S-STEM Scholars earned a total of 157 associate degrees and 116 California Certificate of Achievements.

There was a measurable improvement in student GPAs in the seminal math and science courses after participating in the CCC S-STEM Scholars Project, and the number of units taken was higher as well.

Our student participants received tremendous support from the program staff, faculty, and fellow students. Besides encouragement from their mentors and program staff, they also received extensive information on how to apply for transfer schools, scholarships, internships, and job searches. According to our survey, students felt confident pursuing their goals. Those who participated in the summer internships reported high satisfaction with the quality of the projects, mentors, and group dynamics. They also felt that their work enhanced their problem-solving, analytical, teamwork, and communication skills. They experienced a renewed sense of energy and enthusiasm, which they shared with other students and faculty members during seminars. They encouraged other students to apply for internships.

The National Science Foundation S-STEM funding has allowed Contra Costa College to achieve higher persistence, retention, and success in science and math-based curricula and to support students in transferring to bachelor’s-level institutions.

References: National Center for Education Statistics
NCES College Navigator - Contra Costa College

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: Mark Wong

Contra Costa College (CCC) S-STEM Scholars Project

According to the fall 2022 data from the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES), 78% of the students received some form of financial aid, and 48% received Pell Grants. Increased      student support programs at institutions of higher education:      To provide an array of support services to ensure the successful      progression of students from entry to degree completion and into careers      in STEM fields.
Increased      the number of well-educated and skilled employees in technical areas of      need: To provide more STEM graduates from      underrepresented groups to meet the burgeoning regional and national need      and expand diversity in the technology workforce.



We achieved these goals using a multipronged approach:

Selecting      up to 30 students each year and enrolling them in courses of study in      science, mathematics, English, and engineering.
Providing      academic advising through the counseling office and weekly mentor      meetings.
Offering      academic support activities through workshops and tutoring.


Providing      selected students with work and research experience that shows the real      practice of science and engineering.


Organizing      scientifically relevant seminars and discussions twice a month.
Organizing      academic trips to places with a focus on science, technology, and      engineering.
Encouraging      the participation of science faculty in activities that increase their      knowledge and abilities in how students can learn to do science.



The CCC S-STEM Scholars Project has a devoted cadre of mentors and advisors from the college and STEM-related institutions. These individuals are experienced scientists who share their knowledge and provide emotional and moral support to our students.

During the COVID-19 lockdown, we continued our support program remotely. Thus, our funding allowed us to extend the support program to eight years.

Transfer Schools:

Universities      of California: 68
California      State Universities: 32
Private/Out-of-State      Universities: 6
Total      transfer students: 106



Status of Transfer Students:

Graduated      with a bachelors degree: 60
In      bachelors degree program: 30
No      information found: 16
In      graduate school: 14
Working      in STEM-related fields (while in bachelor's program and/or after      graduation with a bachelors degree): 75



The S-STEM Scholars earned a total of 157 associate degrees and 116 California Certificate of Achievements.


There was a measurable improvement in student GPAs in the seminal math and science courses after participating in the CCC S-STEM Scholars Project, and the number of units taken was higher as well.

The National Science Foundation S-STEM funding has allowed Contra Costa College to achieve higher persistence, retention, and success in science and math-based curricula and to support students in transferring to bachelors-level institutions.
